content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear instruction, easy and quick to solve, all tests and validators are correct (I solved it in the IDE).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think this contribution is easy to understand and I was abled to write a program in just a few miuntes.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think making the input two separate lists and adding a provision for empty lists elevates this to a suitable Clash puzzle. The two lists would make this a bit more of a challenge as a Reverse, but still should be solvable. I was able to code up a Ruby solution in about a minute. Coders using C will be at a disadvantage for both Timed and Shortest because the syntax of the qsort function is a bit arcane and requires a comparator, but them's the breaks.

Goal section
* Please format "Empty" as a {{constant}} and remove the quotation marks.

Input section
* Please add the following in front of the current descriptions:
   • <<Line 1>>: An integer
   • <<Line 2>>: An integer
   • <<Next [[n1]] lines>>: An integer in each line which is an element of
   • <<Next [[n2]] lines>>: An integer in each line which is an element of

Output section
* Please add "or {{Empty}}" to the end of the description.

Constraints section
* Please change "len(L1)" to "[[n1]]".

* Please change "len(L2)" to "[[n2]]".

Stub generator
* Lines 3 and 4: Please change "i" to some other names, because the default code may not be correct in some languages, e.g. i is used as the loop variable in Python3:

for i in range(n_1):
    i = int(input())
for i in range(n_2):
    i = int(input())

Thanks.
Done it ! Thank you for the suggestions.
